title: DraftKings ads have taken over the MBTA, too - Massachusetts news
text:
DraftKings isn’t limiting its seemingly non-stop advertising blitz to the small screen.
The Boston-based daily fantasy sports company was one of the top five advertisers with the MBTA for September, MBTA spokesperson Joe Pesaturo said. Partly buoyed by DraftKings’s ads, the T took in $3.16 million in ad revenue in September, its best month ever.
So what does that money translate into? A trip to South Station proves that.
 Draft Kings did a station buy in South Station? This is the biggest I've ever seen on the MBTA... pic.twitter.com/V1TrMONehP
— Dave Levy (@levydr) September 14, 2015 Welcome to the Draftkings Dukakis Center at South Station sponsored by Draftkings. Draftkings. pic.twitter.com/Vq0ebAm1Mq
— Tom McLaughlin (@tmclaughbos) September 24, 2015 DraftKings has also purchased wraparound ads on two MBTA buses (seen above) for the price of $8,500 every four weeks per bus, Pesaturo said.
DraftKings’s ad strategy on public transit isn’t limited to Boston, either. Their ads have been plastered around public transit buses in cities across the country, including in Chicago...
Saw this earlier. Draftkings is taking over! This is a CTA bus! pic.twitter.com/UABNIl7QFX
— Juan Hernandez (@jdez_xo) September 17, 2015 ... in Charlotte...
Draft Kings is everywhere...including this Charlotte city bus. pic.twitter.com/xBTxMjAwqz
— Colleen Thomas (@colleenthomas_) September 28, 2015 ...and in San Francisco.
. @DraftKings knew I wasn't watching the game. Not pictured @FanDuel rickshaw that follows this bus around pic.twitter.com/Xr4EnfBi1O
— Mark Sparhawk (@sparhawk) September 29, 2015 Those widespread ads have come with their own political cost. The fantasy company has faced increased scrutiny in recent weeks, largely as a result of the attention that comes with all that advertising.
